WITH reference to my despatch No. 797 of the 31st October, and to my telegram No. 246 of the 12th November, 1910,1 have the honour to forward herewith a despatch from His Majesty's consul at Bussorah reporting that the authorities have waived their objections to the registration of the property of Sheikh Mubarek of Koweit and Sheikh Khazal of Mohammerah. I have, &c. GERARD LOWTHER. BUSH! RE R:S!DENCY. Reg No Enclosure in No. 1. CONflOcNTiAL h£C0H0S. Consul Crow to Sir G. Lowther. (No. 2.) Sir, Bussorah, Januarg 11, 1913. WITH reference to previous correspondence on the subject of the refusal of the authorities at Bussorah to permit the registration of laud and house property in the names of Sheikh Mubarek of Koweit and Sheikh Khazal of Mohammerah, 1 have the honour to report as follows :— A telegram has been received from Constantinople by the vilayet to the effect that the services of Sheikh Khazal and Sheikh Mubarek are highly esteemed by the Government, and that the Sultan is pleased with them. _ The acting vali, Ali Reza Pasha, on receipt of this telegram, sent Ahmed Nairn Bey to Failieh to inform the sheikhs, but as they were absent he has decided to communicate the message to them by letter. As regards the question of Sheikh Khazal, it will be remembered that in the time of Suleiman Nazif Bey the Tapoo office were instructed by Constantinople not to register any property in Sheikh Khazal's name. More recent instructions have been received by this department, allowing the sheikh to acquire property in houses and shops, and I hear that Sheikh Khazal has now begun to purchase houses. I am informed that after Hassan Reza Bey, former vali, left Bussorah, Sheikh Mubarek wrote to the vilayet asking why his land purchases were not allowed to be registered in his name. He stated that he had rendered good service to the Ottoman Government in the time of Midhat Pasha, former Vali of Bagdad, by going to Hassa and driving bin Saoud out of that district, and that he had always paid his taxes and given pecuniary assistance to the Government. He urged that the authorities should not suppose that he bought the land for other people, as they could do so themselves, and it was unreasonable to imagine that they wanted his assistance. He asked for a clear statement of the objections to his purchases. I am informed that Sheikh Khazal also wrote to the vilayet in similar terms, stating that he preserved good relations with the local authorities, and often captured runaway criminals and returned them to Bussorah. He asked for the reasons of their refusal to the registration of his land. Both sheikhs requested that instructions might be issued permitting the registration of property in their respective names. The Administrative Council discussed the matter and decided to support the requests of both sheikhs, informing the Minister of the Interior that there was no objection to register the lands acquired by Sheikhs Khazal and Mubarek in their respective names, and pointing out that Sheikh Mubarek had given £ T. 500 towards the relief of the sufferers in the fire at Constantinople, and £ T. 3,000 to the war fund during the Turco-Italian War ; and that Sheikh Khazal had given £ T. 400 to the Turco-Italian War fund, and £T. 300 during the present war. titleInfo.title: 'File 53/44 II (D 36) Sheikh Mubarak's Fao and Faddaghiya Properties'

physicalDescription.extent: File is arranged in chronological order, from earliest at beginning of the file to most recent at end.An index of the topics discussed in the file is contained on folio 1A.

Condition: A bound correspondence volume.Foliation: The file's main foliation sequence commences at the index page and terminates at the last folio; these numbers are written in pencil, and can be found in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.The file contains the following foliation errors: 1A and 1B.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence between British officials regarding a decision taken by the Ottoman Tapu Office to allow the registration of properties in Iraq in the names of Shaikh Mubārak Āl Ṣabāḥ of Kuwait and Shaikh Khaz‘al bin Jābir al-Ka‘bī of Mohammerah.On ff 14-15 the file contains copies in English and Arabic of a document entitled 'Assurances to Shaikh of Koweit regarding his property on the Shatt al Arab dated 3rd November, 1914'.
